üíî Fallout 4: A Review from a Retired Steward
Played on PC | Modded via Vortex | Over a decade of Bethesda loyalty

Fallout 4 once stood as a beacon of open-world immersion ‚Äî a place where modders, storytellers, and digital stewards could shape their own wasteland. I was one of them. I built settlements, rewrote systems, and watched the community breathe life into a game Bethesda had left half-finished. But today, Fallout 4 is no longer a sanctuary. It‚Äôs more of a storefront.

üß± The Foundation Was Strong
The Commonwealth was rich with potential.

The S.P.E.C.I.A.L. system offered deep customization.

Modding tools like F4SE and UFO4P turned a an unyielding stiff and unforgiving mess into a playable masterpiece.

Vortex gave me clean control over my load order and workflow.  For others, it was MO2.

For years, I made Fallout 4 my own. I documented breakthroughs, benchmarked mods, and helped others navigate the chaos. It was never perfect ‚Äî but it was ours.

üß® The Fracture: Anniversary Edition
Bethesda‚Äôs decision to release a paid Anniversary Edition in 2025 shattered that trust. Instead of honoring the modding legacy, they broke it:

Script Extender compatibility destroyed

Modding tools rendered obsolete overnight

Locked in improvements ‚Äî a method of monetization (I said this with a bit of anger and resentment.  I'm willing to admit when I haven't been fair.)  Some are enjoying the Anniversary Edition mod enhancements.  Some complain of game breaking situations and crashes, but my guess would be they are talking about already modded installs and F4SE will break your game if the version number changes.  This update changed it big time, and you can count on continued updates along the way as new Creation Club content is added‚ÄìJUST LIKE SKYRIM SE did and here's the thing:

Skyrim SE still survived and the modding community still rallied around it and thrived.

No, they didn‚Äôt consult the player community, but some modders were consulted. They didn‚Äôt warn us. They simply pushed an update that disrupted workflows, broke load orders, and forced modders to scramble. It didn't seem like much of an upgrade, but I can't honestly swear it wasn't.  Some players like these new mods that were added and some complain they can't get the game to launch.  Whose fault that is‚Äìthe player who modded their game and didn't remove the mods or Bethesda that released the executable update with a desktop breaking but‚ÄìI can't really say.

üß† A New Vision That Doesn‚Äôt Include Us
Bethesda and Zenimax have made their direction clear: they‚Äôre chasing a new generation of players who don‚Äôt know what came before. They‚Äôve chosen monetization over stewardship. Paid mods, TV tie-ins, and shallow updates have replaced the deep engagement that once defined their worlds.

I‚Äôm not angry. I‚Äôm exhausted. My breath feels wasted on a studio that no longer listens. Fallout 4 was once a canvas. Now it seems more like a billboard.  Like I said, "it will go on."  Some modders will adopt the new Creation Club until they realize the only mods actually being used from all of their hard work are either the ones bundled in the Anniversary Edition who Bethesda already paid for, things that can be found on other sites for a more modest fee or no fee at all.

üõ°Ô∏è The Pause
I‚Äôve removed Fallout 4 from my system 2 days prior to the release of the Anniversary Edition knowing pretty much any mods would break the new one. I won't be trying to mod Fallout 4 for some time because it will take quite a while before mod authors decide what they wish to do.  Maybe I‚Äôll return someday but I will probably try the game as is. If the community rebuilds, I will celebrate with others. But for now, I mark this moment as The Steward‚Äôs Pause.

Fallout 4 was a masterpiece in the hands of its players. Modders were responsive to the players and gave them what they wanted.  Bethesda took Fallout 4 back ‚Äî with a $20.00 USD price tag.  I'm recommending the game because of the level of nostalgia it brings me in the Wasteland.  Since I have the option to add the Creation Club content or keep the Game of the Year Edition, I prefer to choose which mods I install and don't.  That's a personal preference. A Commonwealth Reborn: Reassessing the Strengths and Weaknesses of Fallout 4
Abstract: This paper offers a contemporary review of Bethesda Game Studios' 2015 action role-playing game, Fallout 4. It argues that despite valid criticism, the game represents a significant evolution in the series through its refined combat, deep crafting systems, and the groundbreaking Settlement feature, which fundamentally alters the player's relationship with the post-apocalyptic world. However, this praise is tempered by a critical examination of one of the game's most persistent technical shortcomings: the excessive reliance on loading screens, which frequently disrupts immersion and the flow of exploration.

Introduction: Into the Wasteland, Again

Upon its release, Fallout 4 was met with the unique duality of critique that often greets massively ambitious sequels. It was simultaneously praised for its leap forward in gameplay mechanics and criticized for perceived simplifications in its RPG elements. Years removed from the hype cycle, this review posits that Fallout 4‚Äôs enduring appeal lies not in its faithfulness to a purist ideal of the genre, but in its successful execution of a new, more visceral and player-driven vision for the wasteland. It is a game that trades some narrative nuance for unparalleled environmental storytelling and systemic depth, creating a playground that continues to captivate players long after the main quest concludes. Yet, this experience is consistently punctuated‚Äîand sometimes hampered‚Äîby a frustratingly archaic technical limitation.

The Refined Art of Survival: Combat and Crafting

The most immediate and impactful improvement in Fallout 4 is its combat. Moving beyond the serviceable but clunky shooting of its predecessors, the gunplay now feels weighty, responsive, and genuinely satisfying. Weapons have a tangible impact, and the Vault-Tec Assisted Targeting System (V.A.T.S.) has been smartly reworked. Instead of pausing combat entirely, it now slows time, creating a more fluid and dynamic integration of strategic targeting and real-time action. This modernization makes encounters with the Commonwealth‚Äôs myriad dangers, from feral ghoul swarms to the imposing might of a Deathclaw, more thrilling and less a battle against the game‚Äôs own mechanics.

This combat excellence is married to a deep and rewarding crafting system. The "junk" that was once merely a source of caps is now a vital resource. Every desk fan, hotplate, and piece of duct tape can be broken down into components essential for weapon and armor modding. This system creates a powerful feedback loop where exploration directly fuels character power. Finding a rare laser rifle is no longer the end goal; it is the beginning of a project to customize it into a unique instrument of destruction, tailored to the player‚Äôs specific style. This layer of personal investment in one's gear is a masterstroke, making the player's progression feel earned and deeply personal.

Building a Legacy: The Settlement System

Perhaps Fallout 4's most significant and innovative contribution is its Settlement system. This is not a mere side activity; it is a fundamental recontextualization of the player's role. You are no longer just a tourist in the apocalypse, looting ruins and moving on. You become a catalyst for rebirth. The ability to clear, secure, and build thriving communities across the Commonwealth is a powerful fantasy.

The system, while occasionally finicky, offers staggering depth. Players can construct elaborate multi-story structures, establish defense networks, cultivate food, and manage supply lines between settlements. This transforms the world from a static backdrop into a dynamic canvas. A dilapidated drive-in becomes a fortified trading hub; a lonely island is turned into a self-sufficient fortress. The system creates emergent storytelling, where a settlement‚Äôs desperate defense against a raider attack becomes a memorable player-generated event. It provides a tangible sense of purpose beyond the main narrative, making the player‚Äôs mark on the world permanent and visible.

The Immersive Sim of Environmental Storytelling

While the dialogue system and main questline have been points of contention, Fallout 4‚Äôs world is a masterpiece of environmental storytelling. The Commonwealth is a character in itself, dense with untold narratives waiting to be discovered. Bethesda‚Äôs expertise in crafting poignant vignettes is on full display. A skeleton clutching a wedding ring next to another in a bathtub tells a tragic story without a single line of codex text. A hidden bunker filled with pre-War supplies and a final farewell note on a terminal provides a moment of quiet humanity. These moments are everywhere, rewarding curious players with pockets of profound narrative depth that are often more compelling than the central plot. The world feels lived-in, scarred, and quietly yearning for the hope that the player can ultimately provide.

A Harsh CritiQue: The Tyranny of the Loading Screen

For all its ambitious steps forward, Fallout 4 is anchored by a glaringly outdated technical flaw: the excessive and frequent loading screens. In an open-world game whose greatest strength is immersion and seamless exploration, the constant interruption of loading is a significant detriment.

The problem is twofold: frequency and duration. Entering nearly any interior cell‚Äîbe it a major faction headquarters or a small shack‚Äîtriggers a loading screen. This design choice, a holdover from the game‚Äôs Creation Engine roots, creates a pervasive sense of fragmentation. The desire to quickly pop into a building to sell loot or complete a task is stifled by the knowledge that it will involve two separate loading interruptions. This "door-to-wasteland" loading breaks the rhythm of play and serves as a constant reminder of the game‚Äôs artificial boundaries.

Furthermore, the length of these screens, particularly on base hardware at launch, could be egregious. Wait times of 30 seconds to a minute were not uncommon, turning a simple errand into a test of patience. While solid-state drives in modern consoles and PCs have alleviated this issue significantly, the fundamental design remains. In an era where other open-world titles were seamlessly streaming vast landscapes, Fallout 4‚Äôs reliance on this archaic method feels like a stubborn anachronism that actively works against its core strengths of exploration and immersion.

Conclusion: A Flawed Masterpiece of Player Agency

In conclusion, Fallout 4 is a game of profound contrasts. It is a title that soars on the strength of its systemic gameplay, offering a refined combat loop, a deeply engaging crafting and modification system, and a revolutionary Settlement feature that empowers the player like never before. Its world is a dark, beautiful, and heartbreaking tapestry of environmental stories.

Yet, it is undeniably hampered by its technical legacy. The overabundance of loading screens is a persistent thorn in its side, a recurring interruption that undercuts the very immersion it works so hard to build. It is the single biggest argument against the game‚Äôs otherwise stellar design.

Despite this critical flaw, Fallout 4‚Äôs positives ultimately outweigh its negatives. It succeeds not as a perfect RPG, but as an unparalleled simulation of post-apocalyptic life. It gives players the tools to define their own experience, to rebuild, to explore, and to carve out a corner of the Commonwealth to call their own. It is a messy, ambitious, and deeply rewarding experience whose heart‚Äîthe joy of building something new from the old world‚Äôs ashes‚Äîshines brightly enough to make its frustratingly frequent loading screens a burden worth bearing.

Fallout 4 really shows you what the Commonwealth is made of. Step outside that vault and you will see a world that is hurting, sure, but you will also see people who have not given up. That is what pulled me in. Everywhere you go, someone needs a hand, and when you answer that call, the whole place starts to feel a little less hopeless.

The settlements are the heart of it all. Some of them are barely holding on, just a few settlers trying to make it through another night. Others are crawling with raiders or worse. But once you clear the threats and put up some defenses, folks start to breathe easier. Build a few beds, plant some crops, set up clean water, and before long the place begins to feel alive again. Watching a settlement grow from a wreck to a real community‚Ä¶ that is something worth fighting for.

The rest of the Commonwealth is dangerous, no doubt, but every safe corner you carve out brings us one step closer to a future people can believe in. That feeling, that sense that you are making a difference, is what makes the journey so rewarding.

If you are willing to stand up for people who cannot do it alone, this game gives you plenty of chances to prove it. The Commonwealth needs you.

Where to begin... Fallout 4 is complicated. On its own, the base game, is lacking at worst and mediocre at best. 

This game does some things right and many other things wrong, yet there is a cavoite that makes this game fantastic and a blast to play that ill get to later. First the positives. I personally really love the art design of this Fallout, whoever designed the textures and models for the non npc and player assets  was thinking outside the box while still giving it that Fallout feel yet how they implemented it was problematic. This Fallout has a more scifi feel then the other titles rather than the grittier more rugged vibe of the previous two games. 

The Commonwealth is massive for a game that came out in the mid 2010's and exploring it is an enjoyable experience. This game has great Dungeon design. The gunplay is fun in the early and mid game all be it very problematic in the very late game with  scaling issues for npc health where npc's become bullet sponges. The Weapon modding system is neat, was a nice upgrade from the past games. Settlement customization is a fantastic and enjoyable addition, yet has a learning curve and time management issue to it. If you put time into designing your settlements its quite extraordinary how you can formulate the development and character of them. More on settlements later its a great addition to the game.

Now on to the Negatives of the Basegame. The story, while having good ideas and a plausible themes about technological advancement with what constitutes the definition of sentient life is terrible written. Emile's (the lead writer for the base game) writing design philosophy for stories of "keep it simple stupid" really holds the writing, character development, and story behind from work that feels like a shallow mess. New Vegas and 3 where you can see the deph and passion in the writting and story is non existent in the base game because it lacks complexity. Nothing against Emile personally, I'm sure he is great game design writer when he wants to write something complex which contains depth with proper pacing and not simple and dumbed down for the sake of not adding to much hourly content from the game.

So yes, the Story for the base game sucks do to the simplistic and dumbed down version of the writing and quest design. Same can be said for a lot of the quest writing. The new factions in theory are conceptualized but are horrible executed in practice with rushed, simplistic writing. Same with the characters and companions, so many great ideas, so terrible executed for the sake of scrunching the writing. Main, Side, and Faction, quests suffer from being great ideas terrible executed. That goes for the whole writing for the entire base game.  The Companions are the best part of the main game story wise, there is some meaningful character development from the majority of them. Though some companions feel like they have personality disorders. 

The RPG elements have been incredible neutered in comparison to New Vegas. It's is especially apparent in terms of tackling quests. RPG Dialogue options are inferior to New Vegas with almost everything being replaced with a flat charisma check pass rather than basing things on other stats. The body textures and gun models are abysmal, the design of pipe weapons and the assault rifle are exceptionally terrible. This game is buggy (as is all Bethesda games) and the precombined system was generated in a way that can kill your fps by ten frames on some systems do to bad optimization. Their is also the Nvidia debris crash problem.... Get to that later. 

So yeah the Base game is mediocre 5 out of 10. With RPG elements, quest design, story writing, and dialog really lowering the score with how they overlap.

So why do I have almost 900 hours in a game that's just mid. That's the thing, the base game is mid. 

Nukaworld is a neat DLC with somewhat interesting characters, a decent story line with quest design that actually plays into rpg elements outside charisma, new mechanics focused around settlements, and great raider rp which was  missing in the base game. Nukaworld like the Commonwealth is fun to explore, some of the side quests are interesting, with the factions actually feeling somewhat well executed. The weapons added in this dlc are fun and wacky. The problem is the simplistic writing structure that the base game has that leaks over into this dlc, again Emile. This dlc doesn't offer much for good karma playthroughs except new places to explore as all the prior things mention require bad karma actions including the settlement mechanics. Your going to get gotye for a reason ill mention later.

Now the Far Harbor dlc is great, best dlc for the game. Beforehand I mentioned when it comes to the story and the writing that it could best be described as great ideas terrible executed? This dlc doesn't have the terrible executed part. The characters actually feel like real people in the post apocalypse. The factions are well implemented with characters that are interesting . Their is rpg choice in dialogue, as well as rpg choice in tackling quests. Far Harbor is well designed from a content standpoint. It expands on the story of one of the more likeable companions in the base game, and adds a memorable companion who feels like a real person with an interesting story. The weapons it adds are cool. Get The DLC, its a reflection of what the base game could have been with better design choices from upper management.

The dlc's bump up the score from 5 to 6.5 automatron just adds a quest and some interesting mechanics get if you want it if you like robots.

Now, to the reason why this game is worth getting in 2025 and why I have almost 900 hours in this game. The mods. Bethesda games has the best modding community out there second to only Rimworld. Fallout 4 probably has the second best modding community ever in the history of gaming. Want to rebalance, redesign, and reconceptualize the factions? There are mods for that. Want new engaging mechanics that level and advance with progression of the game? There is a lot of mods for that. The most horrible designed and executed faction in the game the Minutemen, can become the best designed with the most engaging mechanics with mods from Nexus.  Want an alternative way to go through the main storyline that adds fun and engaging ways that new fun characters? There is mods for that. Well designed quest mods that utilize rpg stuff there are mods for that. Bugs, precombine issues, and that crash problem with Nvidia GPU's, get a mod for them. Ill name same of my favorites here in order.

Sim Settlements 2 with it's chapters, extensions, and Addonpacks, is my personal favorite. Are you tired of spending so much time on building up your settlements? Do you feel it takes time away from your exploration? Do you wish there was a whole other more extensive, well designed, well written, engaging, main story questline that has intriguing characters, great side quest both big and small, with exceptional voice acting and writing that surpasses the base game? Get SS2, it adds so much to this game. Too much to mention. This modd adds loads of new mechanics surrounding settlements. You may be saying, well, I don't like settlements and rather be exploring and enjoying quests. Fine get Rise of the Commonwealth for SS2 and all the Cityplan packs you can fine, place down a city planners desk assign a mayor to it, choose a city plan you like based of the description and watch your settlement progress in 4 stages from foundation to level 3! I think it would be a good thing if Bethesda supported games by releasing bug fixes and free content with some effort behind it -- essentially what CD Projekt Red has done with Cyberpunk in the last few years. Yes, they'll release a few free items as well sometimes, but the quality of them is just laughable, and they essentially serve as ads for the paid "Creation Club" content.

Skyrim and its "Anniversary Edition" were already ruined by this "Creation Club" content, which is so poorly implemented into the game that it is only slightly palatable with mods that completely overhaul it. Fallout 4 fares worse, as it has a smaller modding community than Skyrim, and it seems Bethesda is completely focused on milking this game for "Creation Club" content, releasing update after update that does nothing to actually improve the game and breaks mods each time. The game has actively gotten worse over the past several years, and it's to the point where I'm not sure if I'll ever play it again.

The base game itself has a well-designed world that is really fun to explore, good companions, and stellar encounter design. The gunplay is satisfactory. All of this positive is severely dampened by the game's writing, which is borderline nonsensical at points, and its awful dialogue system. I've enjoyed the game a lot over the years, but the juice is not worth the squeeze of dealing with a company that does not care about the game, but just uses it solely as a microtransaction vehicle.
